value: The City Park, featuring the Kris Eggle Memorial Fountain and the Rotary Pavilion

is a city in the state of

.  The community has a population of approximately 10,000 within city limits, and over 40,000 within the surrounding two counties.  Established as an industrial town, Cadillac was originally known as the Village of Clam Lake.  The Village was incorporated into a city in 1877, changing its name to Cadillac.  The area became a popular tourist destination following World War II, and remains so today.  

Cadillac is the gateway to northwest Michigan.  Nearly a million visitors come each year to the area, to enjoy the scenic lakes and quaint small town.  While popular, Cadillac is quiet and makes a great Northern Michigan destination for summer and winter recreation enthusiasts.

Lake Cadillac lies entirely within the boundaries of the City.  This feature has led to a geographically unique community, with most city commerce taking place on the east shore of the lake—the downtown—while many businesses catering to tourists are located on the west shore.  Locals refer to this western portion as

. Knowing this terminology can be helpful if you plan to stay in the area.

The residents of Cadillac and the surrounding area, like most Midwesterners, are open and friendly.  If you need directions, locals will be happy to assist.  Visitors are also welcome to ask for advice on where to get a tasty lunch or, if needed, a quick repair for their bicycle.
Driving is the only practical means by which to visit Cadillac.  The primary route,
is used by visitors from the
and Lake Michigan, passing through Cadillac on its way to Lake Huron.  Be sure to enjoy the scenery of Northern Michigan on your way to Cadillac.
offers bus service to Cadillac from various Michigan cities.
, accessible to private aircraft, lies approximately two miles north of the downtown area.

Personal automobile is the most convenient means of getting around, with free parking available around the city. Parking downtown is convenient and plentiful, even during major events.  

Biking is highly recommended for those staying on or near the lakes.  Cadillac has a bike path along the shores of Lake Cadillac, so each-west travel between the downtown and the Cadillac West is convenient.  Biking on the local streets is safe, and there are a number of nature trails in the area that provide great off-roading.  Rental facilities are available

. 

Walking around the downtown area is easy and safe.

The
runs a demand response bus service.  In the summer the Authority runs a mid-day fixed-route service. The line runs between Cadillac West and the downtown.

Cadillac surrounds Lake Cadillac and part of Lake Mitchell.  The downtown is adjacent to the former, and public docks make it easy to tie up a boat and walk to shops and food.

Many of the restaurants around the lake provide docks. 

Launching your own boat or renting is highly recommended.  A number of local businesses rent out watercraft
.  If you rent a campsite at Mitchell State Park, you are allowed dock up your boat alongside of the canal.
The downtown, which includes a number of quaint shops, a movie theatre
and a park, is picturesque.   It is popular with tourists year-round.

value: content=Adjacent to the downtown, part of the original Village of Clam Lake. Many of the homes in the District are large, Victorian-style residences built by the lumber barons and businessmen who helped establish Cadillac more than a century ago.

content=Constructed originally to transport logs from Lake Mitchell to the mills on the shores of Lake Cadillac. It is now used exclusively by recreation lakecraft. With the canal, the two lakes comprise approximately 3700 acres of open water.

The Cadillac area is very popular with tourists who favor active recreation activities.  The city surrounds Lake Cadillac and is adjacent to Lake Mitchell.  There are a number of public boat ramps; there is a launch on the northwest side of Lake Cadillac, in Kenwood Park, while on the northeast end of Lake Cadillac, next to City Park and the downtown, there is another ramp.

value: content=6083 E MI-115. Waterslides, mini-golf, batting cages and go-carts. Arcade activities indoors.
content=5465 E 46 1/2 Rd. Open Memorial Day through Labor Day. Pond fish for rainbow trout, feed deer and other animals. Great for small children.
content=Truly unique hands-on sculpture on the shores of Lake Cadillac. Native materials, primarily silver maple, beach, and ironwood were used to make this set of sculptural instruments.
.  Located between the two lakes.  It is home to the
http://www.michigan.gov/dnr/0,1607,7-153-10365_10887-31273--,00.html Carl T. Johnson Hunting and Fishing Center
, which documents the history of hunting and fishing in Michigan. The Center is open year-round.  There is also a 2.5-mile (4.0 km) nature trail that leaves from the Hunting and Fishing Center.
.  Lies east of Cadillac and is part of the Pere Marquette State Forest.  The trails of the Pathway are well suited to biking, hiking and cross country skiing.
.  Lies immediately to the west of Cadillac.  The national forest is popular with ORVers
content= 18 hole public golf course. The Cadillac Grill Restaurant is on site.
content= 27 hole public golf course. Views of Lake Cadillac.
content= Established in 1910, the Cadillac Country Club course is a 6017 yard, par 70 classic.
content=This jazz-in-the-park series is offered nearly every Thursday in the summer. Downtown Cadillac, City Park, Rotary Pavilion.
content=Annual New Years Even celebration held at various locations throughout the city. Music, games, face painting, dog sleds, petting zoo, displays of local artists' works.
content=Held every winter, over frozen Lake Cadillac. Events include snowmobile racing, sleigh rides and an ice fishing tournament.
content=Selections change daily. Offers seafood and fine international cuisine.
content=Carry out and delivery. Locally famous for its pizza.
content=American cuisine. Located in Cadillac West, on the shores of Lake Mitchell.
content=(MI-115). Italian cuisine. Located on the southwest shores of Lake Cadillac, in Cadillac West. Docks available for boaters.
content=Popular downtown eatery with live music every Friday night.  Wine, beer, and mixed drinks, too.
content=Sports bar with a full kitchen.  Easily the most upscale bar in town.  Well lit.
content=Loud music, usually crowded to the rafters on ladies' night.  Go there to drink, not to talk.
content=Comprised of two separate bars: Sally's Northwood Lounge upstairs, Sally's Down Under in the basement.
content=Primarily for bikers.  May want to avoid if you are not a tough guy.  Shares a building with Cadillac Party Lounge, use the left door for the Party Lounge.
content=Free popcorn.  Attached to McGuire's Hotel.  Features karaoke some nights.
content=Attached bowling alley and pizza restaurant.  Popular with the young folks (particularly the under-21 set).
content=Also known as "Stopless Topless".  Topless dancing.  Do not bring the girlfriend or kids.
content= Standard rooms with double or king beds, studio rooms with fireplaces and deluxe suites are available. Tennis courts, pool and sauna, 27 holes of golf.
content= 70 guest rooms and suites, indoor pool, whirlpool and fitness room.
content= 36 guest rooms in MacKenzie Lodge, with year-round heated pool and hot tub. Ski slopes with 34 Runs, rental shop, day lodge with cafeteria and bar; 9 holes of golf.
content= 4 bedroom home on Lake Mitchell, beautiful lake sunsets. Close to many golf course, 2 ski resorts.

content= This state park lies between Lakes Cadillac and Mitchell and in fact straddles the canal connecting the two lakes. There 221 campsites, with modern toilet buildings, showers and sanitation stations. Eight campsites are wheelchair-accessible. A mini-cabin is also available for rent. Reservations are strongly recommended, especially for the sites along the canal.
content=Private campground, located 3 miles (5 km) to northeast of the city. It has a number of amenities including a petting zoo, a pool and internet access.
is 1 hour north on MI-115 and MI-37.
